linkTarget.anchoringText: The Johan Sverdrup field, discovered by Lundin Petroleum in 2010, is currently classified as the fifth largest oil discovery on the Norwegian continental shelf. The field, outlined in Figure 1, is located 140 km offshore on the western coast of Norway and covers an area of approximately 200 square kilometers. The reservoir section within the Intra-Draupne Formation Sandstone is relatively homogeneous with Darcy to multi-Darcysand, and the thickness is between 40-70 meters in the central parts of the field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Outline of the Johan Sverdrup field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Outline of the Johan Sverdrup field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 2 shows a general overview of the process. Previous studies showed that the kh was the main uncertainty parameter affecting the DST responses. Hence, the isochore thickness and reservoir permeability are included with uncertainty in order to obtain updated values. Other input parameters such as oil-watercontact, relative permeability, fault transmissibilities etc. are fixed throughout this study.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Overview of the integrated reservoir modelling workflow established on the Johan Sverdrup field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Overview of the integrated reservoir modelling workflow established on the Johan Sverdrup field

linkTarget.anchoringText: The residual field account for uncertainty in the seismic interpretation, it is modeled as a Gaussian random field with a spherical covariance function. The variogram range of the residual field varies according to a normal distribution, with a mean range of 2000 m, and a standard deviation of 1000 m, sampled values below 200 m is set to 200 m. Four random realizations of the residual surface are displayed in Figure 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Four realizations showing the generated residual surfaces for the isochore thickness. Red areas indicate increased isochore thickness and blue indicates reduced thickness

formatted-caption.caption-text: Four realizations showing the generated residual surfaces for the isochore thickness. Red areas indicate increased isochore thickness and blue indicates reduced thickness

linkTarget.anchoringText: As a mean to bypass this challenge, while still accounting for structural changes in the model during the data assimilation process, we pad the grid by adding 20 extra meters to h0, below the base of the Intra-Draupne Formation (20 additional layers). Then we activate/deactivate cells in this padded grid as the isochore thickness is changing (by setting the porosity to zero for cells in the padded grid) as illustrated in Figure 4. All four scenariosevaluated include the structural uncertainty.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Handling structural uncertainty in the model by padding the existing grid (green cells), then activating or deactivating grid cells (orange cells) in the simulation model according to changes in the isochore thickness (red line). Yellow color illustrate the sand filled cells, while gray cells indicate shale

formatted-caption.caption-text: Handling structural uncertainty in the model by padding the existing grid (green cells), then activating or deactivating grid cells (orange cells) in the simulation model according to changes in the isochore thickness (red line). Yellow color illustrate the sand filled cells, while gray cells indicate shale

linkTarget.anchoringText: Scenario 1: Constant horizontal permeability away from the wells, established using interpolation of permeability values obtained from the analytical PTA, shown in Figure 5.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Permeability trend map used in modelling Scenario 1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Permeability trend map used in modelling Scenario 1

linkTarget.anchoringText: We model the spatial variability similarly as the isochores (where the vertical variogram direction varies according to a normal distribution, with a mean range of 5 m, and a standard deviation of 3 m, where sampled values below 1 m are set to 1 m). Four realizations of the generated permeability fields are shown in Figure 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Four realizations showing permeability in one horizontal layer of the model for Scenario 2

formatted-caption.caption-text: Four realizations showing permeability in one horizontal layer of the model for Scenario 2

linkTarget.anchoringText: The standard deviation is 10 Darcy for both rock-types. Again, we use a spherical covariance function adding uncertainty in the range parameter as described in Scenario 2. Figure 7 displays two realizations showing the facies and permeability for one horizontal layer of the model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Two realizations showing the facies and corresponding permeability in one layer of the model for Scenario 3

formatted-caption.caption-text: Two realizations showing the facies and corresponding permeability in one layer of the model for Scenario 3

linkTarget.anchoringText: Scenario 4: We apply the same approach as scenario 3, where we replace the mean of the Gaussian latent parameter with the background trend parameter shown in Figure 8. The trend parameter was manually constructed to improve the fit of the DST data. The probability of rock type 2 is increased close to 16/3-8 S and 16/3-5, while keeping a preference for rock-type 1 around 16/2-6 T2 and 16/3-4. Further, we model the permeability conditioned to the rock types as in scenario 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Mean of the Gaussian latent parameter used in Scenario 4. Red areas indicate an increased a priori probability of rock type 2, while blue areas indicate an increased probability of rock type 1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mean of the Gaussian latent parameter used in Scenario 4. Red areas indicate an increased a priori probability of rock type 2, while blue areas indicate an increased probability of rock type 1

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Two realizations showing the facies and corresponding permeability in one layer of the model for Scenario 4

formatted-caption.caption-text: Two realizations showing the facies and corresponding permeability in one layer of the model for Scenario 4

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 and Figure 11 display the simulated and observed pressure derivative response for the 200 models before and after conditioning to the observed data using an ensemble smoother. Please note that because of the high permeability and downhole shut-in, the early time unit slope during wellbore storage is finished within one second of the buildup and is therefore not visible in the observed pressure data with a sampling rate of one second. In the conditioning, we assume a log-linear increase in the tolerance from 0.01 log-cycles to 0.05 log-cycles for the duration of the buildup period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Pressure derivative response for wells 16/2-6T2 (left) and 16/3-5 (right) before and after conditioning using an ensemble-based approach. Blue lines represent calculated pressure derivatives from the models, while black circles represent the observed pressure derivatives

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure derivative response for wells 16/2-6T2 (left) and 16/3-5 (right) before and after conditioning using an ensemble-based approach. Blue lines represent calculated pressure derivatives from the models, while black circles represent the observed pressure derivatives

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 and Figure 11 display the simulated and observed pressure derivative response for the 200 models before and after conditioning to the observed data using an ensemble smoother. Please note that because of the high permeability and downhole shut-in, the early time unit slope during wellbore storage is finished within one second of the buildup and is therefore not visible in the observed pressure data with a sampling rate of one second. In the conditioning, we assume a log-linear increase in the tolerance from 0.01 log-cycles to 0.05 log-cycles for the duration of the buildup period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Pressure derivative response for wells 16/3-8S (left) and 16/3-4 (right) before and after conditioning using an ensemble-based approach. Blue lines represent calculated pressure derivatives from the models, while black circles represent the observed pressure derivatives

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure derivative response for wells 16/3-8S (left) and 16/3-4 (right) before and after conditioning using an ensemble-based approach. Blue lines represent calculated pressure derivatives from the models, while black circles represent the observed pressure derivatives

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12 illustrates the estimated median of the difference between the generated sand thickness, h, and the best guess surface, h0 for all members in the initial and updated ensemble consisting of 200 models each. As seen from this figure, the thickness in the initial ensemble of models is unbiased with respect to h, while for the updated ensemble, we observe clear spatial trends where both the thickness is increasing and decreasing.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Median of the difference in sand thickness (200 model realizations vs. initial best guess thickness surface, h0) for the initial (unconditioned to DST data) 200 ensemble members (top) and updated (conditioned to DST data) 200 ensemble members (bottom). Red/blue color indicates and increase/decrease in the sand thickness. We outline the area defining the Avaldsnes High region by the magenta colored polygon

formatted-caption.caption-text: Median of the difference in sand thickness (200 model realizations vs. initial best guess thickness surface, h0) for the initial (unconditioned to DST data) 200 ensemble members (top) and updated (conditioned to DST data) 200 ensemble members (bottom). Red/blue color indicates and increase/decrease in the sand thickness. We outline the area defining the Avaldsnes High region by the magenta colored polygon

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: updated (conditioned to DST data) 200 ensemble members

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 13 further illustrates the effect of the DST data conditioning on the structural uncertainty. In particular, we notice that the P10 estimate for the thickness in the area between wells 16/3-8S and 16/3-5 approaches h0, implying that a certain thickness is required on the central part of the Avaldsnes High region to match the DST data in these two wells. Similarly, we need to reduce the potential upside (P90 estimate) for the thickness in the area northeast of well 16/3-4 to match the DST data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Estimated P10 (left) and P90 (right) of the difference in sand thickness (model realization vs. initial best guess thickness surface, h0) for the initial (unconditioned to DST data) ensemble members (top) and updated (conditioned to DST data) ensemble members (bottom). Red/blue color indicates and increase/decrease in the sand thickness

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimated P10 (left) and P90 (right) of the difference in sand thickness (model realization vs. initial best guess thickness surface, h0) for the initial (unconditioned to DST data) ensemble members (top) and updated (conditioned to DST data) ensemble members (bottom). Red/blue color indicates and increase/decrease in the sand thickness

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: initial (unconditioned to DST data) ensemble members
updated (conditioned to DST data) ensemble members

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 14 and Figure 15 display the median and P10/P90 estimates for the permeability in one selected layer of the grid before and after conditioning to DST data. We notice the general trend of increased permeability in the area between wells 16/3-8S and 16/3-5, where the median permeability estimate increases from 50 Darcy to 60-80 Darcy and the P10 estimate is between 50 and 60 Darcy in large continuous areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Estimated median permeability in one selected layer of the grid for the members before (top) and after (bottom) conditioning to DST data in the four wells on the Avaldsnes High area

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimated median permeability in one selected layer of the grid for the members before (top) and after (bottom) conditioning to DST data in the four wells on the Avaldsnes High area

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 14 and Figure 15 display the median and P10/P90 estimates for the permeability in one selected layer of the grid before and after conditioning to DST data. We notice the general trend of increased permeability in the area between wells 16/3-8S and 16/3-5, where the median permeability estimate increases from 50 Darcy to 60-80 Darcy and the P10 estimate is between 50 and 60 Darcy in large continuous areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Estimated P10 (left) and P90 (right) permeability in one selected layer of the grid for the members before (top) and after (bottom) conditioning to DST data in the four wells on the Avaldsnes High

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimated P10 (left) and P90 (right) permeability in one selected layer of the grid for the members before (top) and after (bottom) conditioning to DST data in the four wells on the Avaldsnes High

linkTarget.anchoringText: Analyzing the bulk and in-place volumes before and after conditioning to the DST data (Figure 16) we see that the low case (P10) volumes are lifted 20 %, while the high case (P90) volumes are lifted 5 %. This effect is not surprising considering the effects seen in the estimated statistics for the thickness of Intra Draupne Sandstone shown in Figure 12 and Figure 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Relative difference in the estimated bulk and in place volumes before and after conditioning to DST data

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relative difference in the estimated bulk and in place volumes before and after conditioning to DST data
